messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:38): huh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:38): notices a revert request that he'd somehow missed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:39): good thing i happened to browse the archives
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:39): tries to work out what he's supposed to be reverting
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:41): aha, something to make validators not catch inaccessible content
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:41): the mind boggles
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (09:46): what's accessible is an opinion
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:01): foolip, when I paste entire source of http://schema.org/TVSeries into http://foolip.org/microdatajs/live/ then try the tabs, the entire page goes blank
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:01): (though there doesn't actually seem to be any MD in it)
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (10:02): ... if I cut from  <div id="mainContent">  and below, the UI still works and I see { "items": [] }
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I think the TR page probably is the latest web notifications draft. That spec seems to have stalled
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:05): ah
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:06): Also, isn't timeless' name just "tim eless"? That would rather seem to exclude him from a "three people who go by pseudonyms walk into a bar" joke
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:07): um, no
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:07): his name is josh soref :-)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:07): Ah. Well he's back in the joke then
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:07): Dunno where I got the other idea from
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:08): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: is ==date-or-time-content== used anywhere? http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/MicrosyntaxDescriptions
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:08): (especially since I recognise his real name now you mention it)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:10): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: also what's with the claims that the formats differ from the spec?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:14): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: looks like it's dead code
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:14): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: there used to be some element (<time>?) that accepted date or times in element content
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): yeah <time> did that for aw hile
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:15): <meter> and <progress> also had similar magic with numbers
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:21): removed it
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:21): that page still needs stuff filled in
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:42): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i don't thikn we should have args in HTML spec
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:42): it's not interoperable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:43): really?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:43): who doesn't do it?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:44): IEs don't, iirc
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:44): and mozilla provides another argument
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:44): to the callback
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:44): well if it's just IE then they can get with the programme
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:44): before the user specified argument(s)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:44): really?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:45): https://developer.mozilla.org/En/Window.setTimeout
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:45): see "lateness"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:45): window.setTimeout(function(a,b,c) { alert('a=' + a + '\nb=' + b + '\nc=' + c) }, 1000, 1, 2, 3);
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:45): ...alerts "a=1 b=2 c=3"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:45): in firefox
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:45): what's arguments.length?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:46): and opera
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:46): and chrome
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:46): seems interoperable to me!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:47): 3 in opera and chrome, 4 in firefox
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:47): so they stick it after the user-supplied args?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:47): yup
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:48): should we implement lateness in opera and chrome?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:49): why? can't you do it yourself in script?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:49): i guess the script could do new Date yeah
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:49): grab date.now() when setting, grab it when the callback runs, subtract the delay you specified...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:49): i have heard pretty much zero authoring interest in this argument
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:49): to the point that i never had even heard of it :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:50): 353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320: that doesn't work if the machine was suspended in between
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:50): well nobody uses arguments
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:50): i use them all the time :-)
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:50): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: depends on how the implementation handles that
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:50): nobody who authors and has to care about IE does :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:50): does the monotonic clock from web perf increment when timeouts don't?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:50): people who care about IE don't use a _lot_ of the stuff in this spec
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:50): the monotonic clock from web perf isn't actually specified
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (10:50): 353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320: you could use lateness without using arguments
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:50): so nobody knows wtf it does
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:51): well ok then
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:51): someone should get on that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:51): calls "not it"
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:51): yeah it's just microsoft guys
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:51): who keep bothering me to put a "implementations should not ..." section into a normative section
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:51): i explained that wouldn't mean anything and their response was "we're fine with that"
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (10:52): normative shoulds make me want to hit things
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (10:52): at least, after dealing with the XMPP specs where half the spec is shoulds
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:52): 353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320: well hopefully you don't have an actual "should" in a non-normative section
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:53): i haven't put the sentence anywhere cos it's a dumb requirement
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:53): it'll end up being implementation advice in a note
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:53): aah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:53): push back against bad ideas
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:53): don't give in!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:54): ok i should go sleep
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:54): nn
132ea029b178e3c6d3a3aa4521ea24a5 (10:55): is a normative  Should a passive aggressive spec?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:57): i can see that you are satisfying the minimum required requirements of this standard, but do you really want to just be a minimally compliant implementation?
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (10:57): Stan over there is meeting 37 individual requirements...
